video.title: Python for Beginners – Full Course [Programming Tutorial]
video.description:
Learn the Python programming language in this full course for beginners! You will learn the fundamentals of Python and code two Python programs line-by-line. No previous programming experience is necessary before watching this course.

🔗 Start using Replit: https://join.replit.com/python-students

✏️ Beau Carnes developed this course. Check out one of his other channels: https://youtube.com/zizyo

💻 Rock, Paper, Scissors Code: https://replit.com/@BeauCarnes/rps-python
💻 Blackjack Code: https://replit.com/@BeauCarnes/blackjack-python

🏗 Replit provided a grant that made this course possible.

🔗 The Python Handbook by Flavio Copes: https://www.freecodecamp.org/news/the-python-handbook/

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐️
⌨️ (0:00:00) Introduction

Rock, Paper, Scissors Intro Project
⌨️ (0:03:11) RPS - Variables and Functions
⌨️ (0:09:07) RPS - Calling Functions
⌨️ (0:12:31) RPS - Dictionaries
⌨️ (0:15:28) RPS - User Input
⌨️ (0:16:55) RPS - Libraries, Lists, Methods
⌨️ (0:20:45) RPS - Function Arguments
⌨️ (0:22:33) RPS - If Statements 
⌨️ (0:25:40) RPS - Concatenating Strings
⌨️ (0:27:13) RPS - f-strings
⌨️ (0:30:26) RPS - Else and Elif Statements
⌨️ (0:33:37) RPS - Refactoring and Nested If
⌨️ (0:38:37) RPS - Accessing Dictionary Values
⌨️ (0:41:55) RPS - Testing Game

Fundamentals of Python
⌨️ (0:43:52) Setup Python Locally
⌨️ (0:47:47) Creating New Repl
⌨️ (0:48:45) Variables
⌨️ (0:51:21) Expressions and Statements 
⌨️ (0:52:38) Comments
⌨️ (0:54:23) Data Types
⌨️ (1:00:16) Operators
⌨️ (1:00:44) Arithmetic Operators
⌨️ (1:03:52) Comparison Operators
⌨️ (1:05:13) Boolean Operators
⌨️ (1:07:26) Bitwise Operators
⌨️ (1:07:42) is & in Operators
⌨️ (1:08:21) Ternary Operator
⌨️ (1:09:40) Strings
⌨️ (1:12:36) String Methods
⌨️ (1:16:41) Escaping Characters
⌨️ (1:19:23) String Characters & Slicing
⌨️ (1:21:45) Booleans
⌨️ (1:26:07) Number Data Types
⌨️ (1:28:19) Built-in Functions
⌨️ (1:29:50) Enums
⌨️ (1:32:51) User Input
⌨️ (1:34:39) Control Statements
⌨️ (1:36:48) Lists
⌨️ (1:46:21) Sorting Lists
⌨️ (1:49:57) Tuples
⌨️ (1:53:49) Dictionaries
⌨️ (2:01:45) Sets
⌨️ (2:06:10) Functions
⌨️ (2:16:57) Variable Scope
⌨️ (2:18:35) Nested Functions 
⌨️ (2:21:37) Closures
⌨️ (2:22:59) Objects
⌨️ (2:26:27) Loops
⌨️ (2:32:01) Break and Continue
⌨️ (2:33:02) Classes
⌨️ (2:39:12) Modules
⌨️ (2:45:55) Arguments from Command Line
⌨️ (2:52:42) Lambda Functions
⌨️ (2:54:51) Map, Filter, Reduce
⌨️ (3:02:41) Recursion 
⌨️ (3:04:42) Decorators
⌨️ (3:06:45) Docstrings
⌨️ (3:09:54) Annotations
⌨️ (3:11:30) Exceptions 
⌨️ (3:17:09) With
⌨️ (3:18:26) Installing Packages with pip
⌨️ (3:21:39) List Compression
⌨️ (3:23:09) Polymorphism
⌨️ (3:24:23) Operator Overloading

Blackjack Card Game Project
⌨️ (3:26:58) Blackjack - Beginning
⌨️ (3:50:13) Blackjack - Deck Class
⌨️ (3:58:45) Blackjack - Card Class
⌨️ (4:03:25) Blackjack - Hand Class
⌨️ (4:21:13) Blackjack - Game Class
⌨️ (4:37:04) Blackjack - Testing

⌨️ (4:39:36) Conclusion

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://freecodecamp.org/news

replies.author: Robert Simone
replies.text:
@Beau really appreciate your effort and approach you'd taken to simplify Python learning journey.
JFYI: Reduce example @ 3:02:22 throws exception if there are more than 2 examples.
I think, result of reduce on first two expenses is an int, which can not be put back in reduced list.
Below should work (not an elegant solution though):
total = reduce(lambda a, b:("expenses_total", a[1] + b[1]), expenses)

topLevelComment.author: Xero Day
topLevelComment.text:
Great course, but *please* learn how to pronounce "woof" and "lambda"... They do not sound like "wolf" and "llama." The same with "asterisk." The dictionary wants to help you. Also, your explanation of byref and byval passing didn't seem to make technical sense, though I could be wrong. Also, I'm skeptical of calling this python code a "program". It's an interpreted/scripting language, and only compiled code is normally called a "program." And a few times when you talked about doing things "faster," it was really just more convenient, and the computer often has to do a lot more work to provide this convenience, which is typical of scripting languages. Generally, Python is slow because the code is not compiled and not optimized for specific platforms.

This course is really helpful, and correcting the mistakes helps too. Thanks very much for making it :)

replies.author: MichaelHouston
replies.text: You must be fun at parties. It's odd that you took issue with these minor pronunciation mistakes but ignored the biggest (and probably only really significant) error, which is that he says "list compression" when he means "list comprehension".

topLevelComment.author: Nadeem

topLevelComment.author: david10101961
topLevelComment.text:
Excellent, many thanks Beau. The blackjack example suited (pun, oops!) me perfectly as I've played a lot, and hence am familiar with the game rules and mechanics. Also fits in neatly for a tutorial where just a few classes and methods creates a functional basic game, a nice demonstration of how elegant Python coding can be. And it wouldn't be impossibly difficult to add rules for soft hands, insurance, doubling down, splitting pairs, etc.

[EDIT] Also looks like you have 3 enthusiastic young lads there keen to follow in your footsteps, and who will be a big help when it comes to troubleshooting your code in a few years time.  :)

topLevelComment.author: Radin Esque
topLevelComment.text:
I decided to try out and make one simple tweak. So I did below: (on section 42:00 - RPS - Testing the game)

Switched from def check_win(player, computer): to def check_win(computer, player):
Other lines of codes unchanged.

The result, the program runs alright, and the Player-Computer is switched.
When I input my answer (paper for example), it turns out that I am now the Computer; computer chose paper, while Player randomly chosen out of those 3 options.

Curious on why this happened?

Did this to understand more on the function, and how the input inside the parentheses actually works. (left empty, the program error)

@Sebastian Stifter CS50 Course is amazing for a beginner.

replies.author: Sebastian Stifter
replies.text: Yes, this is a pretty bad beginner video for Python. He introduces new concepts in the project phase (Blackjack) and the whole thing is exceptionally complicated for someone who has never coded before. I understand it's meant to show off the capabilities of Python a bit but in the end you're just copying what he's writing because you have no idea what's going on. I recommend the 4hr python for beginners video with the guy from Giraffe Academy. It's much easier to follow. If this is the first time you're introduced to coding concepts, then no wonder people give up straight away.

topLevelComment.author: Abdur Rahim
topLevelComment.text:
The following code started running over for  in replit. Stopped the run and ran again. It was keeping running. Stopped it. Cleared the code and and re-ran it. That time it worked. It gives a feeling that when a block of code is not working in replit, better to clean it and try it. Just in case anyone faces this. 

condition= True
while condition==True: 
    print("Keep running the code")
    condition=False

The "reduce" example doesn't extend to three items.

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "main.py", line 5, in <module>
    sum = reduce(lambda a,b: a[1] + b[1], expenses)
  File "main.py", line 5, in <lambda>
    sum = reduce(lambda a,b: a[1] + b[1], expenses)
TypeError: 'int' object is not subscriptable

topLevelComment.author: Rajeswary Narasimman
topLevelComment.text:
I was wondering how to use the reduce function for 3 values in the list. For anyone looking for the same,
I found the answer by googling. 
lis_tup = [("a", 1), ("b", 2), ("c", 3)]
s = reduce(lambda sum, a: sum + a[1], lis_tup, 0)

topLevelComment.author: Princess Allie
topLevelComment.text:
I found the first 43 minutes of this to be an INCREDIBLE refresher course on everything I learned at the beginning of the summer and feared I'd forgotten after taking way too much time off. I'm excited to jump back in with the confidence of knowing I don't have to restart at print("Hello World!").

To any beginners who think the first part goes way too fast: hang in there! You don't have to understand everything that's happening. Just type along with him and you'll have something cool in less than an hour.

That sense of accomplishment at having completed something is what's needed to drive beginners to keep wanting to learn more complex things. You don't get that by just memorizing the definitions of function and variable. Thanks for all your work on this, Beau!!!
